Set-up OSG to work with ssgrid

Nicholas Ducharme-Barth

2022-09-29

Source: vignettes/setup_osg.Rmd
setup_osg.Rmd

Before being able to unleash the utility of high-throughput computing for stock assessment using OSG and the ssgrid package there are a few things that need setting up:

  1. ssh keys for connection to OSG,
  2. a portable R library containing r4ss so that the R scripts written by osg_r_create() will work,
  3. uploading a Stock Synthesis executable to OSG.

1. ssh key generation

The easiest way to do this is to follow the instructions on the OSG help portal.

In Step 1 of their instructions I would follow the steps for Unix-based operating system (Linux/Mac) or latest Windows 10 versions. If using Windows and PowerShell as your terminal you can skip the chmod 700 ~/.ssh command. Otherwise follow the rest of the instructions.

2. Setting up the portable R library

Similar to step 1, the OSG help portal contains good help on setting up a portable library. Below are the steps needed to create an R portable library that will work with ssgrid.

Step 2.1: login to your assigned OSG login node. I prefer to do this via ssh using your terminal of choice. In this case user your.username will login at node 05.

  ssh your.username@login05.osgconnect.net

Step 2.2: Once logged in, create a directory to house your portable R library.

  mkdir -p R-lib-4.0.2/R-packages
  cd R-lib-4.0.2

Step 2.3: Enter an environment with the appropriate version of R1.

  singularity shell /cvmfs/singularity.opensciencegrid.org/opensciencegrid/osgvo-r:4.0.2

Step 2.4: Declare global variables describing where R to install packages, and launch R.

  export R_LIBS=$PWD/R-packages
  export TMPDIR=$PWD
  R

Step 2.5: Once inside R, check to see if the directory that you created in step 2.1, R-packages, is in the library path.

  .libPaths() # check to see if 'R-packages' directory is in library path

Step 2.6: Still within R, install the remotes and r4ss packages. remotes is needed to install the github version of r4ss2. Follow the on-screen prompts to install the packages, and then exit R.

  install.packages("remotes", repos = "http://cloud.r-project.org/")
  remotes::install_github("r4ss/r4ss",dependencies=TRUE)
  q(save="no")

Step 2.7: Exit the R environment that you entered into in step 2.3. Next tar up your portable R library and delete the uncompressed directory to save space.

  exit
  touch R-packages.tar.gz
  tar -czf R-packages.tar.gz R-packages/
  rm -r R-packages

3. Upload Stock Synthesis to OSG

The OSG help portal contains a page describing how to upload files to OSG using scp. This is the approach that we will take.

Step 3.1: Download a Stock Synthesis linux executable of your choice. Make sure to rename whatever linux version you download as ss_linux since the ssgrid functions will look for that name.

Step 3.2: If you are not still logged into OSG on a terminal, connect to OSG via ssh. Then make a directory to upload ss_linux into. The ssgrid default is to look for a directory called ss_executable. Once the directory is made, close the ssh connection.

  mkdir -p ss_executable
  exit

Step 3.3: Navigate to the local directory you downloaded ss_linux into using your terminal of choice. Next, upload to OSG via scp.

  scp ss_linux your.username@login05.osgconnect.net:/home/your.username/ss_executable/
